Legal_Issue: Whether the visa officer improperly assessed the applicant's work experience and intended occupation under the Immigration Act and Regulations
Evidence_Assessment: Visa officer considered all aspects of the applicant's work experience
Burden_of_Proof: On the applicant to demonstrate error
Legal_Rule: Visa officers must assess applicants based on actual experience, intended occupation, and occupational demand in Canada using the C.C.D.O.
Procedural_Issue: Allegation of improper assessment of work experience
Grounds_for_Claim: Misassessment of work experience and intended occupation
Outcome_on_Merits: No error of law or denial of natural justice found
Review_Standard: Reasonableness standard applied to administrative decisions
Key_Evidence_Considered: Applicant's work history, intended occupation, occupational demand in Canada
Legal_Framework: Canadian immigration law, C.C.D.O. classification system
Applicant_Challenge: Visa officer misassessed qualifications and experience
Defendant_Response: Visa officer properly followed legislative requirements and assessment guidelines
Evidence_Type: Documentary evidence of work experience, job classification data
Legal_Provision: Sections of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act and associated Regulations
Legal_Provision_Cited: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act, sections related to skilled worker assessment
Grounds_for_Inadmissibility_or_Allegatio: Lack of occupational demand and insufficient relevant experience
Applicable_Process: Skilled worker permanent residence application process
Governing_Rule: Assessment must align with C.C.D.O. and demonstrated occupational demand
